title: Dinefwr Park Walking Route

images.caption: An artwork at Dinefwr Park with Newton House beyond. Pat Bullen-Whatling produced this "Celtic Circle" as part of a set of installations at Dinefwr Park. The circle frames Newton House (National Trust)

images.title: David Smith / Woods beside the Deer Park in Dinefwr Park, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Woods beside the Deer Park in Dinefwr Park

images.title: Trevor Rickard / White cattle herd at Dinefwr Park, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: White cattle herd at Dinefwr Park. Looking north towards The Rookery. This pedigree herd has been at the park for over a thousand years.

images.title: Richard Morgan / 'Willow Stag Sculpture' at Welcome Centre, Newton House, Dinefwr Park and Castle, Llandeilo, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: 'Willow Stag Sculpture' at Welcome Centre, Newton House. Pat Bullen-Whatling, whose web site I found at www.patbullenwhatlinggallery.co.uk is the artist that has recently stationed this 'more or less' full-sized 'willow deer' on the edge of the car park at the above National Trust property.

description: Explore the 12th-century Welsh castle, the historic house, the 18th-century landscaped park and the medieval deer park in this large park in Llandeilo. There's miles of nice footpaths taking you to ponds, woodland, a heronry and a number of interesting sculptures. The park is located near to the edge of the Brecon Beacons where you can continue your walking. You could head to the nearby Carreg Cennen Castle which sits on an elevated limestone precipice with fabulous views over mountains of the park. Our circular walk from Llandeilo visits the castle and the ancient woodland at the nearby Tregeyb Wood nature reserve.
